author: ajsutton
content: It makes very little sense to use checkpoint sync and not just start from the current finalized state.  So basically you wind up close to the end immediately. You will normally get <100 new blocks from the CL one-by-one.

author: ajsutton
content: Its more challenging with a node that has been offline for a few days - then it is going to switch to optimistic mode and send you a lot of blocks at once.

author: ajsutton
content:
I suspect ELs will want to optimise the handling of newPayload and fcu calls when they know they're already syncing to do as little as possible and possibly even discard redundant fcu updates (ie if the CL sends 3 fcu updates that you have in a queue, immediately respond SYNCING to the first two and only actually process the third).

Similarly, CLs may wind up limiting fcu calls a bit during sync, particularly if they know they have a whole batch of blocks to import. Not much we can do about newPayload though.
